borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: <p><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The application has failed to demonstrate that the proposed development would&nbsp;<span style="line-height:115%"><span arial="">accommodate appropriate off-street car parking provision, noting that the site does not appear to benefit from any existing</span></span></span><span style="font-size: 14.6667px;">&nbsp;</span><span style="font-size: 14.6667px;">lawful</span><span style="font-size: 14.6667px;">&nbsp;</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;"><span arial="">crossovers. As such, it cannot be ensured that the development will&nbsp;</span></span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;"><span arial="">not negatively impact the existing residents and users of the surrounding area. The application is therefore&nbsp;</span></span>contrary to:</p><div><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">- National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;</span>National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)<o:p></o:p></p><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">- Policy T6.1 of the London Plan (March 2021);</span></p><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">- Policies BR9 and BR10 of the&nbsp;</span>Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</p><p class="MsoNormal"></p><p><span pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">- Policy DMT3 of&nbsp;</span>The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</p></div><p><br></p>

<div>The scale, siting and design of the proposed development would result in direct overlooking an increased sense of overbearingness to the rear garden at no. 36&nbsp;Denham Way,&nbsp;which is intensified by the close proximity between the development and no.36,&nbsp;therefore constituting unneighbourly development and contrary to:</div><div><br></div><div><p><span style="" pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">-
National Planning Policy Framework </span>National Planning Policy Framework
(NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)<o:p></o:p></p><p><span style="" pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">- Policy
D4 of the London Plan (March 2021);</span><o:p></o:p></p><p><span style="" pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">- Policy
CP3 of </span>Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)<o:p></o:p></p><p><span style="" pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">-
Policies BP8 and BP11 of the </span>Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough
Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)<o:p></o:p></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="line-height: 107%;" pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">- The Residential
Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012);<o:p></o:p></span></p><p class="MsoNormal">









</p><p><span style="" pt="" sans",="" sans-serif;"="">-
Policies SP2, DMD1 and DMD6 of </span>The London Borough of Barking and
Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)<o:p></o:p></p></div>

<p>The culmulative impact of the existing and proposed development at the site,&nbsp;comprised of various ad-hoc additions and alterations to the original dwelling and its roofscape, will dominate the dwelling&nbsp;and no&nbsp;longer bear resemblance to the&nbsp;character of the original&nbsp;dwellinghouse,&nbsp;resulting in harm to the appearance of the dwelling, built form and symmetry of the semi-detached pair,&nbsp;and character of the wider area,&nbsp;notably given the location of the application site on a prominent corner plot and siting&nbsp;opposite the&nbsp;Grade I listed Eastbury Manor House,&nbsp; and&nbsp;within the Becontree Estate. As such, the proposed development is contrary to:</p><p>- National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)</p><p>- Policy D4 of the London Plan (March 2021)</p><p>-Policies CP2 and CP3 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)</p><p>- Policies BP2 and BP11 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</p><p>- Policies SP2, DMD1, DMD4 and DMD6 of The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</p>

<p>The proposed 2-bedroom dwelling fails&nbsp;to provide a&nbsp;double bedroom, and one of the bedrooms proposed fails to meet the required width or internal area for&nbsp;a single bedroom.&nbsp;Additionally, the dwelling provides very poor outlook at ground floor and&nbsp;will suffer from a sense of enclosure.&nbsp;In addition to both proposed gardens being undersized, the garden provided at no.4a does not appear to be useable given its shape, which has not been accurately&nbsp;portrayed in the block plan provided.&nbsp;As such, the proposed development introduces sub-standard accommodation that will not facilitate an acceptable living standard for future occupiers, and represents a reduced standard of residential accommodation than the existing family sized dwelling. The proposed development is therefore contrary to: - National Planning Policy Framework (DLUHC , 2021); - Policies D4 and D6 of the London Plan (March 2021); - Policies CP3 and CC1 of the LDF Core Strategy (July 2010); - Policies BP6, BP8 and BP11 of the LDF Borough Wide Development Plan Policies DPD (March 2011); - Policies SP2, SP3 and DMD1 of the Draft Local Plan (Regulation 19 Submission version, December 2021); -DCLG Technical Housing Standards (nationally described space standard) (DCLG, March 2015) (as amended).</p>

<p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 7.5pt;">The applicant has failed to present plans which accurately depict
the&nbsp;proposed development.&nbsp;Specifically the&nbsp;Block Plan (Y1490/2023/01)&nbsp;fails to accurately&nbsp;represent the position and scale of the development proposed. Additionally, the proposed side extension is not shown on the Proposed Front Elevation (Y1490/2023/05).&nbsp;The proposal could
prejudice third parties who may otherwise have wished to comment on the
application; the proposed development cannot be accurately assessed and it
cannot be demonstrated that it would be supported by the Development Plan. As
such, the proposed development is contrary to:&nbsp;</p><p>

</p><p style="margin: 0cm 0cm 7.5pt;">- National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;National Planning Policy
Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021);&nbsp;- Policy D4 of the London Plan (March
2021); - Policy CP3 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy
(July 2010);&nbsp;- Policies BP8 and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development
Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March
2011);&nbsp;- The Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning
Document (February 2012);&nbsp;- Policies SP2, DMD1 and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London
Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission
Version, December 2021)<span style="font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Helvetica, sans-serif;"><o:p></o:p></span></p>
description:
Conversion of
existing dwelling into two houses (1x 4 bedroom and 1x 2 bedroom) including,
ground floor side & rear extension, construction of a rear dormer, to
facilitate conversion of roof space into habitable accommodation and the
addition x2 front porches with a new entrance for the new dwelling (This
application falls within an Archaeological Priority Site)

constraints_details.result: 4 Eastbury Square, Barking, Barking And Dagenham, IG11 9SN
